div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: TUESDAY, JUNE 6, 1905. ENGLAND AND JAPAN.
div.p: Router informs as that the “Times,” in a eading article yesterday, dwelt on the extreme mportanoe of the recent statement of the deader of the Opposition in declaring that the present policy of the Government on the dliance with Japan will be followed out “faithfully and jealously” by any Liberal Government, rhe continuity of our foreign policyis now a-days »sential, and Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman’s ieclaration will be welcomed throughout the mtire Empire. From the days when Lord Rosebery enabled Japan to assert her olaim to be \ civilised Power by assenting to the revision >f our old treaties with her, and when a British Liberal Government resisted the pressure of great European ooalition and refused to join it in forcing the island State to relinquish the jast fruits of her viotories over jhina, friendship with the progressive people )f the Far Bast has been a national and not % party objeot. Both parties have contributed bo building up oar gw>d relations with them, and no party has oritioifced or resisted the process. These relations led naturally to the conclusion of the agreement of 1902. They lead not less naturally, in the changed circumstances of to-day, to an expansion of that agreement into a mutual defensive understanding in Asiatic affairs. It needed foresight and courage to make the agreement three years ago. Lord Lansdown^ happily for us and happily for the peace of the world, possesses both qualities, and deliberately undertook the risk which is inseparable from all treaties that have in contemplation the possibility of war. Events have amply justified his sagacity and his boldness, and have proved, as they so often prove, that a little timely daring is often in thelong run the surest guarantee of peace. Risk, it is undeniable,is involved in the extension of the alliance, as risk was involved in its conclusion. It is, we believe, a lesser risk, while the advantages it promises to both signatories are both greater and more certain. The same considerations whioh induoed Lord Lansdowne to make the allianoe ought, we are oonvinced, to induce him or his suooeasor to be ready to make it anew with a wider scope and in a more permanent form. “A solid allianoe,” said the “Times” yesterday, “for mutually defensive support” would be a mighty factor in securing the peace of the Far East for an indefinite time. That is, indeed, an oljjeot whioh our French friends must desire qhite as earnestly as we do our selves. They can hardly be averse, therefore, to an arrangement which would attain it without any loss or detriment to France, it is in faot to the direct interest of France as Russia’s ally that the attention of Russia should oease to be entirely absorbed in the prosecution of a policy of adventure at the other end of Asia. Absorption in that policy practically deprives Franoe of some of the chief advantages for the sake of whioh she allied herself with St. Petersburg. It was because Russia is a great European Power capable of exercising great influence in Europe, as she showed more than onoe on critical oooasions since the war of 1870-71, that Franoe entered i#to an allianoe with her. It is for the same reason that for a long series of years she has made enormous advances, without, perhaps, any adequate return of a political oharacter, to the Russian State. The diversion of those loans to the prosecution of undertakings in eastern Asia, from whioh Franoe oannot in any event expect to derive much solid political gain, must be a disappointment to her. Whatever may be the oase at St Petersburg, it is realised in Paris that the Russian adventure has tailed, and that the failure is irretrievable. Anything whioh will bring this truth home to Russia oannot but be serviceable to the real interest! of Franoe, and nothing oould bring it Ijome so effectually as a permanent defensive alliauoe between England and Japan. There are, we imagine, many sober thinkers in Russia itself, who, sinoe Togo’s victory, will be reaJy to welcome any factor that will definitely turn away the minds of their rulers from the pursuit of wild adventures on the Pacific and fix them nearer home, where the true interests of Russia and of her ally are involved. Not the least advantage of an extended Anglo-Japauese allianoe in our eyes would be the faot that it might go far to remove ultimately the suspicions and the apprehensions whioh hitherto constituted an insuperable barrier to a good understanding between Russia and ourselves. Such an understanding we believe to be $uite practicable, provided we oould be assured—as by suoh an allianoe with Japan we should be assured—of the maintenance of the “status quo” in Middle and Eastern Asia,

div.head: OVERTURES AT WASHINGTON.
PROSPECTS HOPEFUL.
div.p: -The Italian Ambassador, after a prolonged conference with Count (Jassini on Saturday, conferred with President Roosevelt. The Japanese Minister Takashira was then summoned to, New York and had a* prolonged interview with President Roosevelt in the evening. M. Takahira afterwards stated that no progress could be made until communication had been received from St. Petersburg. (R. )
London, June, 5.

According to the “Standard, ” it is the opinion the American Ambassador at St. Petersburg that it is not likely that the above, mentioned communications will be made for a fortnight, until the excitement has subsided, but it is his personal opinion that the prospects are hopeful. {Reuter. )

div.head: RUSSIAN SQUADRON SIGHTED.
div.p: Hong Kong, June 5.
One ship of the Russian volunteer squadron, 2 torpedo-boats, one cruiser, and several trans- ports have been sighted 240 miles south-eastwards of here. ( Reuter. )

div.head: DISARMING SHIPS AT MANILA.
div.p: Manila, June 5.

div.head: DISARMING SHIPS AT MANILA
div.p: Admiral Enquist asked permission to repair here, The American authorities report that the ‘ Oleg” will require 60 days, the “Aurora” 30, and the “Jemtchug’ 7. Admiral Enquist says ' that he left the scene of battle on Saturday night and did not know that it continued on Sunday. (Reuter,)
Washington, June 5.
The United States have ordered the immediate disarming of the Russian warships at Manila. (Reuter. )

div.head: APPOINTMENT FOR GEN. TREPOFF.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 5.

General Trepoff has been appointed assistant Minister of the interior and head of the Police and Gendarmerie with extensive powers throughout the Empire. He retains the Governor Generalship of St. Petersburg. {Reuter. )

div.head: IMPORTANT RUSSIAN ! RESIGNATIONS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 5.
Admiral Alexoieff has resigned the Vice-royalty of the Far East, and M. Bulyguin his appointment as Minister of the Interior. The resignations have not been accepted. (Reuter, j

div.head: THE ANGLO-JAPANESE ALLIENCE A “TIMES” ARTICLE.
div.p: The “Times, ” in a leading article, remarks that the importance ot Lord Lansdowne’s statement regarding the alliance with Japan is heightened by Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman s subsequent declaration that any Liberal Government would follow faithfully and zealously Lord Lansdowne’s policy. The 'Times” proceeds that we are confident that there can be no stronger bulwark for the future maintenance of peace in Asia than a solid alliance between Great Britain and Japan for mutually defensive support. The moment is ripe for suck a step. (Reuter. )

div.head: CHANNEL FLEET IN A FOG TWO COLLISIONS.
div.p: On Saturday night, as the Channel Fleet was steaming here, it was enveloped in a dense fog near Dover, owing to which the battleship “Ciesar” collided with the S. S. “Afghanistan, which sank and 18 persons were drowned. The battleship “Triumph” also collided with the battleship “Swiftsure” and the latter was badly damaged. The “Ciesar” and ‘Triumph” are both slightly damaged. (Reuter. )

div.head: KING ALFONSO IN LONDON. RECEIVED BY PRINCE OF WALES.
div.p: King Alfonso has left here for London. (It. )

King Alfonso, escorted by the warships, reached Portsmouth at noon and was received by the Prince of Wales, who accompanied him to London. It rained incessantly but a large crowd welcomed the King on his arrival, Extraordinary police precautions were taken to ensure his safety. (Reuter. )

div.head: M. LOU BET TO VISIT MADRID.
div.p: President Loubet has accepted the invitation of King Alfonso to visit Madrid in the autumn. (Reuter.;
M. Loubet will visit King Alfonso at Madrid in October next.
Chamber of Deputies. —M. Doumer stigmatised the attempt on the King of Spain’* life. His words were greeted with load applause. (Havat. t

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Hampshire beat Worcestershire. Captain Greig scored two centuries. (Reuter. )
The Cairo Water Company has commenced to work the pumps of the artesian wells at Rod el-Farag.

div.head: H. M. S. “Juno,"
div.p: which convoyed the Admiralty dredger “St Lawrence” from Malta to Alexandria, left our harbour again early this morning.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Mousky district of Cairo during to morrow night and at daylight on Thursday will be poisoned by the police.
OuR Stamboul contemporaries publish a new list of subscriptions towards the Hedjaz Railway Fund, bringing up the general total to Piastres Turkish 82,848, 550.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: The management of the Casino inform us that a grand concert will be given there on Sunday next at 10 a. m., when the orchestra will be composed of 50 musicians.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 1st and 2nd inst 17 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these 11 were British, 1 French, 3 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Norwegian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 485, 144. 28.

div.head: Police Bribery
div.p: A court martial will be held at the Alexandria Gouvemorat to-day to try a policeman for having taken a bribe to the amount of P. T. 5 from a bicyclist, who was riding without a light after dark.

div.head: Lands at Ghizeh
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has ordered two powerful pumping installations from Europe. They will be used to convert some lands to the east of Gbizeh into sefi irrigation and will be set up at the mouth of El Khachab canal.

div.head: Our Confreres
div.p: M. Charles Camel, manager of the “Journal du Cairo, ’ is going to Europe on leave to-morrow by the Austrian boat. M. G. Vayssie, general manager of the Havas Agency and editor of the “Journal da Cairo, ” is leaving on the 16th inst by the Messageries steamer.

div.head: The North German Lloyd’s
div.p: steamers to Naples and Marseilles are nearly full up for the forthcoming departures. In tact, all the cabins for the sailing of- 14th June are booked. The next departure after that of the 14th inst. will be on July 5, and many applications have already been received for berths by that boat, so it will be necessary for persons intend-ing to leave by that steamer to book at once.

div.head: The Union Artistique Francaise
div.p: is giving a dramatic performance, followed by a ball, on Saturday next at the new Casino de la Con-ronne, Ibrahimieh. The programme includes the well-known comedy, L’ete de la Saint• Martin, a humorous conference entitled La Femme, and a one-act farce, Lee Boulingrins, The performance will commence at 9. 15 and at 11. 30 dancing will be engaged in. The union is to be congratulated on its new locale.

div.head: Alfonso XIII. at Paris
div.p: The young King of Spain, who has just made such a stir in Paris, is a very enlightened and highly intel? ligent young man. Many Berlitz pupils will, no doubt, hi delighted to know that he was at one time their fellow student, having learned English by the celebrated system of teaching to which Mr. Berlitz has given his name. The Berlite schools have thus been royally honored, after having won public favor throughout the entire world. [Advt. ].

div.head: A Descendant of Mohamh)
div.p: The death is announced of the Newab Begum of Murshi-dabad, at the age of 71. She was the widow of the late Sir Syed Ali Khan, G. C. I. E., Newab Bahadur of Murshidabad. There were several children of the marriage, but only two daughters survive. Prince Syed, the heir, died in 1803. The Begum was a descendant of the Prophet Mohamed, and was remarkable for her charities and her interest in the education of women. At the Diamond Jubilee she was decorated with the Imperial Order of the Crown of India.

div.head: The Priestess of Osiris
div.p: Archteologists in Paris will in a few days be in a position to view the whole of the rich Egyptological collections recovered by M. Gayet daring his excavations among the huge cemeteries of ancient Antinoe. Besides the tomb of Khelmis, the magical dancer, and the victors in the Olympic games, a new monument of the highest interest has been received. It is that of Glethias, “the clothier of the images of Osiris of Antinoe.0 All the crowns, garlands, thvrses of flowers, as well as the objects used by the priestess in perfuming and adorning the statue, have been recovered.

div.head: LA Revue International^! d’Egypte,
div.p: of which the second number/ has just been issued, has evidently oomofo stay, which is a matter of congratulation, for it fills what was a decided want yd the literature of the country. The presents' number is quite as interesting as its predecessor, and contains among other thing* seasonable articles on “Lea Habitations Economiquea et les Cit* Jrtrdins en Egypte,’ by M. F. Bourgeois ; ‘ I* Tuberculose en Esrypte,” by Dr. Vallaso poulo'; “La constitution et la fertility de U terfe arable d’aprfcs les recherches raentes,” by M. Victor Mosseri ; “Richard Wagner ei Mathilde Wesendonck,” by M. V. Nourisson, etc., including the translation of a timelj article on the present crisis at the A1 Azbai University from the pen of a ulema. Altogether, a decidedly interesting publication.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE IN VIENNA. RECEIVED BY THE EMPEROR.
div.p: The Khedive has bad an audience of the Emperor Francis Joseph. (Reuter.)
H.H. the Khedive has paid a visit to the Emperor. (Havas.}

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
div.p: Our Medinet el-Fayoum Correspondent writes : — The cotton /worm has appeared in the villages of Agcr^in and Nazleh. Some of the worms have been tent to Cairo to be examined. Mr. Kuppell arrival at the Fayoum on Saturday and left for Nazleh to aid in fighting against tho worm. Our Minet el Kamii Correspontot state* that the following are tho villages of Minet el Kivmh Markaz in which the cotton worm has appeared :—El Magazer, Kafr El Sohby, Kafr el Walaga, El Bakkashin, Kafr Abd-Allal* Shoufas, and El Shokr.

div.head: THE GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY!
div.p: This company, which is the first of those to be formed under the programme of the Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company, as to the character and scope of which we recently gave our readers particulars, was registered at the Mixed Tribunals on the lgth ultimo. It has been formed with the object of takingNiyer from the parent company an area of 9,000 feddans of laud situated on the west bank of the Nile and extending northwards from Ras el Khahg. As this property stands at present it may be divided into four parts according to its condition, as fully cultivated, partly cultivated, fallow, and wastes Of the fuLy cultivated land there are 2,100 feddans, which it is expected will in 1906 yield an income of about £4,500. Although the remaining 7,000 feddans consist of three different qualities of land, in estimating the probable return to be had from them it has been wisely determined to regard the whole as conbktiug of land reqairing reclamation. The prospects thus obtained are therefore bated upon a very moderate estimate of the probabie returns and will almost certainly be exceeded in the aotual working. Prior to the purchase of this property, Sir William Willcocks caretuUy examined an4 reported most favorably upon a large tract of Government waste laud adjoiuing it which the company desire^to acquire. The purchase of this is, however,\in abeyance owing to the decision of the Government not to sell any large parcel of its lands at present The capital of the company has been fixed at £400,000, the whole of which has been subscribed, and it is anticipated that in 1913 the company will have realised from sales and revenues large profits and will be in a position to pay a dividend exoeeding 10% from the ►,000 feddans that will then remain in its possession. As we have indicated, the probable profits have been purposely estimated below the figures that might have been assumed if the company had been actuated by no other desir* than that of presenting its prospects in the most favorable light, but the course followed by the company is one deserving of the hight est commendation and one that cannot fail to add largely to the interest that will certainly be taken in its future.

div.head: SUDAN SLAVE TRADE.
div.p: Captain McMurdo, the director of the Rer prassion of Slave Trade Department, is now making a tour of inspection in the Sobat region and the Upper Nile districts, in order to satisfy himself as to the measures that are being takeu in those parts of the Sudan for hindering the traffic in slaves. There can be no doubt that the slave trade, though it has as yet by no means been stamped out, has received a very great check in the Sudan. The people have learned to respect, and also to dread, the slavery laws. Seventeen persons were convicted of dealing in slaves during the course of the past year. Of these, one (Ibrahim Wad Mah-moud; was sentenced to death for murder and rebellion. The remaining sixteen were condemned to various terms of imprisonment. The fear which the application of the law has* inspired produces, without doubt, a salutary effeot on the whole, bat it sometimes leads to sad consequences. As regards Sudanese domestic slavery, as distinguished from the slavtf trade, as much progress as could reasonably be expected is being made in eradicating this institution from the country. By carefully protecting the interests of those who were previously slaves, and it the same time gradually employing them on remunerative work in other capacities— should they be unwilling to return to their masters as ordinary servants—the authorities will eventually,with the concurrence and assistance of the inhabitants themselves, gradually transform the status of slavery, and substitute for it a system of paid labour, whioh will probably bo acceptable to master and servant alike. Captain McMurdo's inspection in the south-t3rn Sudan will lead to the control of the slave traffic in those far off regions. The slave raiding cases, which occur in that part of the Sudan, appear to be more in the way of reprisals arising from tribal quarrels than for purposes of export. When the machinery of the Slave Trade Repression Department throughout the Sudan is satisfactorily organised, slavery will have reoeived its death-blow,

div.head: NILE NAVIGATION,. TONNAGE CERTIFICATES. SERIOUS Charges
div.p: “Nothing is more encouraging to the fiscal reformer,” says Lord Cromer in dealing with the subject of Nile Navigation in his last Report, “than to observe the manner in which the country responds to any measures taken, in the direction of the relief of fiscal burthens.” The allusion is to the extraordinarily large increase which has taken plaoe in the boat traffio on the Nile since the look tolls were removed. The traffio is growing enormously, but the figures are not available, save in one case—that of the locks at the Delta Barrage. In 1845^15,867 boats passed through this look. At the close of 1900, the tolls were removed. In 1903, no less than 35,732 boats passed through the look. In 1904, the number increased to 41,740. At the Kasr-el-Nil bridge at Cairo, the officials in charge have given op trying to oount the boats. They pass through in such a rush and in suoh dose order, that it is impossible to oount them. These facts and figures, imperfeot though they be, are sufficient to show that there has been an enormous increase in the river traffic. It will almost certainly develop still further, now t^hat the lioense fees on boats have been removed It is, however, to be anticipated that every year steam-bargcs—of which there are already a considerable number—will take the place of sailing-boats. We regret to state, however, that there is a great deal of abuse in oonneotion with the tonnage measurements and a wide-spread system of fraud is in vogue. A Cairo correspondent gives the following examples of the abuse. We quota his letter in fall “In connection with the recent interest taken in matters of navigation on the Nile, 1 wish to draw attention to a long-standing abuse whioh it is high time shoald be stopped. I refer to the tonnage measurement of native boats, for which, as you maybe aware, certificates are issued by the Government, in the form of receipts for the navigation dues. In selling or purchasing produce, etc., or chartering boats, it is the custom to use these reoeipts very often as the basis of the transaction, which is a oonvenienoe and economises time and trouble. Now comes in the abuse. I have myself seen i^the hands of boatmen, two different certificates for the same boat, showing a very considerable difference in the tonnage. The second one, which is as much as fifty or a hundred ardebs less than the actual measurement, is of course used in purchasing, and the other in selling or chartering. The false one is of oourse obtained by the use of the inevitable nimble dollar, but considering the amounts involved I think it is high time a refonn ii made. I would therefore, whilst apologising for occupying your valuable spaoe, ask your assistance in drawing attention to this matter, with a view to the establishment ot some satisfactory standard of tonnage.”

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LTD.
div.p: A notice will be found in another column of to-day*8 issue of the approaching flotation of tha important new combine, the Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt, Limited. The names of the directors are a guarantee of the soundness ot the enterprise, and there is every prospect that the capital will be largely over-subscribed All the great cotton houses, such as Messrs. Carver Bros.Co., Ltd, Choremi Benachi and Co., J. Planta and Co., C. M. Salvago and Co., C. G. Zervudachi and Co., and the Soci4t4 d’Egrenage de Zagazig, have undertaken not to gin exoept with the combine. All the properties purchased from the above firms have been paid for in shares of the new oompany.

div.head: CAIRO’S NEW BOURSE
div.p: The contract of purchase Of the land on which the Khedivial Bourse buildings are to be erected inCairohss been signed, with theSocidtd Immobilize. The land in question forms part of the Sabet estate, one part of which was bought by the Nungovich Hotels Company. The latter has deoided to enlarge the Savoy Hotel on the Sabet estate side and to open a new street leading from Kasr el Nil-street to Soliman Pasha-avenue. Shops are to be constructed in the new street. The plot sold to the Khedivial Bourse is situated on the border of Kasr-el Nil-street, where the frontage will be. The cost of purchase and construction will be covered by an issue of shares.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL AND BRITISH SHIPPING.
div.p: Sir H. Vincent asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer in the House of Commons this day week if his attention had been called to the declaration on May 22 ot a dividend for the past year by the Suez Canal Company, which would give the British Government a dividend j for the past year of nearly 28 per cent;, free of taxes, on the investment of4,000,000 in 1875 ; and if he would consider the desirability ot refunding to British toonage passing through the Canal last year some proportion, say, 5’Oih 10pe( \',nt, of the dividend, having regard to the charges it had to meet to earn such an incoiriefor the oompany. The Chancellor of the Exchequer : According to the s^onncement in the publio Press a substantial reduotion in the shipping dues will be proposed at the annual meeting of the oompany. I should not be justified in proposing a grant in aid of a particular seotion of British shipping on the ground stated in the question. Sir H. Vincent said he would call .attention to tbe 8»bj*ot on the ewlint poMibl* ooouion.

div.head: THE GHIRGAH SCANDAL. HEARING OF WITNESSES.
div.p: Assiout, Son day. To-day began the^ hearing of the famous Ghirgeh case. The lawyers oame from Cairo on Saturday morning together with Aly Bey Abou el Foutonh, Substitut du Piquet The sitting was opened at 8 o’clock this morning under the presidency of Mohamad Bey Saleh, assisted by Hassan Bey Husny and Abdul Aziz Bey Mohamed, the clerk being Abdul Hamid Eff. Hamdi. The attendance in Court was very large, many having oomespe. cially from Cairo, the Fayoum, and Sohag, where the Moudir is v. ell-known. The president announced the opening of the sitting, after which the names of the were called out and they were given chairs to sit on during the trial. The names of the wit-were then called out and these were accommodated in a special room. There were eleven witnesses for the proeeoution and twelve for the defence. After the usual interrogatories of the aooos-ed the Substitut called for the application of Article 180 of the Penal Code against them. The aoonsed were then asked as to whether they were guilty or not guilty of the charge, and it is ioportant to give here the answers of each. The Cadi Shari and the two witnesses of the tawkil, as well as Kamel flft>Waesif(the wekil of the daireh), asserted that the tawkil was genuine. Mohamed Bey Rifi’a deposed that he was in Cairo and therefore could not tell whether his father had signed the tawkil or not, but he thought he must have signed it as he had intended doing so^ The Moudir asserted that he knew nothing about it, that he was not present, and so could not tell whether it was genuine or a forgery. The clerk then read out the charge^heet, aftes which the witnesses were heard. The most important witnesses were Badawy Bey Rifa’at, Sheikh Ahmed Mansour (the clerk who wrote out the tawkil), and Mohamed Eff. Farghali, son-in-law of Badawy Bey. All ed, of course, that the tawkil was forged but it is very important to note one or two points in the testimony of Badawy Bey. The Moudir is aconsed of having ordered Badawy £ey to sign the-tawkil, telling him that it was a register of the Moudirieh oonoeming the property^ the daira. Badawy Bey, iil his evidence, asserted that the Moudir had not ordered him to sign, nor did he say anything, but was merely present K»m*il who had asked him to sign. The clerk of the Mehkemeh asserted also that “a gentleman” (he did not know whether it was the Moudir or some one else) had asked Badawy Bey to sign. But Moh. Eff. Farghali stated that Badawy told him that he signed through the influenoe of the Moudir. The hearing continued at 9 o’olook in the evening. To-morrow the rest of the witnesses will be heard and the pleadings will take plaoe on Tuesday. (By Telegraph). Assiout, Monday afternoon. The Court today heard the evidence of the Commandant of Polioe, who was present with the Moudir in the house of BaaawiBey. He declared that the Moadir was not oonoerned in the matter either bv his verhal orders or by the exertion of his innaenoe.
Assiout, Tuesday morning. To-day the speeches of the counsel for the defence were heard.

div.head: BIOHMO BRIGANDAGE CASE.
div.p: ( From our ^Correspondent ). Fayoum, Sunday. The moudirieh oonncil has sentenced the omdeh ofBiohmo to three months’imprisonment for his conduct in the recent brigandage case. Many people consider the sentence a harsh one, as during the 15 years he has acted as omdeh there have been no previous complaints as to the way in which he has carried out his duties, and he has, in fact, been officially commended for the way in which he has performed them. No doubt his oondnct was cowardly on the ocoasion of the attaok on Soliman Said’s house, but the experience was a trying one for him. He has been unaccustomed to use firearms, and the suddenness of the outrage caused him to lose his presence of mind. Perhaps the oounoil thought that by making an example of him they would warn other omdebs of the necessity of being prepared to act in cases of emergenoy. These brigands, instead of being imprisoned, should be sent away out of the oountry to the Su^an. They belong to an organised body who furnish the means for their defenoe, ard provide for the families of any who get caught and imprisoned. The State has to pay for their maintenance in prison, and no good whatever is effected by sending them tbere. Let them be sent right away instead.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Thc .S.S. “Roman Prince,” from Antwerp, left ^ondon on Sunday last, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head: NOTES FROM LUXOR. DEATH FROM SUNSTROKE
div.p: The heat here is unbmmbim Resident of Luxor have not known it to ha so hot for many years, and tha hot winds to continue for such a long spell Yesterday an Italian was found dead on the Bayadeah Canal, some kilomeSmi from here. He had arrived from Cairo thssadays ago, and being in straitened circumstances, it appease that he was attempting to walk to Assouan. He did not go £ar, however, before the sun strook Mm and laidhn low. A gentleman, who knew him here, says he leaves a wife and five ohUdran, and used to be formerly in easy circumstances. Soundings are being taken at fiuufc in the Nile, so no doubt the building of the Baoege there will oommenoe next year

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALS Les vices de la reorganisation
div.p: Les etudes de reorganisation municipale.ont pris deax ans.il n’ya cependant presque rieride chang^ k I’ancienne redaction dn rkglement in terieur, mais les rares innovations qni y ont ete introduces valent la peine d’etre, signaler. II y avait, entre autres, ceci dans le texte primitif, art. 35: “Tout membre de la Com **' mission peat n tout momont prendre con “ naissance dans les bureaux mfirnes de la “ Delegation de toutes pieces dont il aura fai “ la demande au secretaire. ” .jC’etait \k on article genant pour les gens qui tiennent k traiter lenrs affaires eonJidentieUe rnent. Grace k ce texte un conseiller qu’on avait elimine fcdesaein delacombinaisonpouvait jeter un coup d’coil profane aur les papiers secrets. Le nouveau texte ne le lui permet plu«. II est ainsi con^u “Tout conseiller pourra “ demander k l’Administrateur les renseigne “ ments ou communications utiles d I’exercice ' de son mandat." Ce n’est plus an secretaire i]%’il faut s’adresser, mais il 1 administrateur, ce qui reud la demarche pins ennnyeuse. L administrateur pourra d’ailleurs repondre dans la m -j >rite des c^is au conseiller scrutateur:“Avez* vous un mandat ? Mfilez-vous done de vos affaires.” On sait que la Commission est ennemie de la presse, e’est-k-dire de la lumifcre. Elle a merne une telle animosite contre lesjonrnalistea qn’elle n'a pas hesite a sacrifier un de membres parce qu’il avait demande leur admission aux seances de la Commission. M.^ Alderson (e’est le membre en> question) a eu beau reduire ensuite ses exigences et reclamer simplement r admission des conseillers munici-paux aux seances de la Delegation; il etait condamne. On repondit k son ultimatum en approuvant sa demission. Ce qui montre bien que la Commission n'a eu d’autre but que de se debarrasser de M. Alderson, e’est qu’elle a vote sa proposition : Art. 30.— “Tout membre " de la Commission pent assister aux seances “ de la Delegation sans y prendre la parole. ” Dans de telles conditions, nous croyons que M. Alderson a le droit de reprendre sa place au aein da college sans rien demander a personne. C’est l’ela da people et non de ses collogues et le subterfuge imagine pour l’ecarter est absolu ment illegal. II y a encore dans le nouveau reglement in-terieur quelques legeres modifications dans le m6me sens; mais nous passons outre pour ar-river e notre' conclusion: Le rfcglement inte-rieur nouveau, n part de legfcres variantes qui n’exigeaient pas deux ans d’examen,est le m6me |ue le rfeglement ancien. La question capitale est de l’appliquer. Jasqu’ici la Manioipalite ne s’est guere preoccappee de s’y conformer et il y a tout liea«de croire qu’il en sera de m§me a l’avenir. Le rouage du controle, qui existe dans toutes les bonnes administrations, n’existe pas dans notre administration Municipals Les infractions aux r^glements, qu’elles soit cOmmises par l’administretion, par la Delegation ou par la Commission ne sont susceptibles d’aucun appel, fante d’une autorite chargee du controle. Ce vice radical qui a jasqu'ici paralyse tous les efforts peraiste et le comite de reorganisation n'a rien imagine poor le faire disparaltre. L’ancien oomme le nouveau reglement portent, par exemple, que si l’ordre du joar d’une seance n’est pas epuise, la discussion sera con tinuee les jours suivants ; qn'k l’ouverture de chaque seance, il sera donne lecture du procos-verbal de la seanoe precedente ; qu’en mature d’allocation, le vote devra toujours porter d’abord sur la proposition comportant l’alloca-tion; que pour les nominations et quand il s’agit d’une question de personne, le vote aura lien an scrutin secret, etc. etc. Ces clauses ont toujours ete impunement vioiees, parce qu’il n'existe paa de comite de contrfile aaquel on paisse adresser ses acclamations en cas d’in-fraction. Le oomite de reorganisation n’ayant pas combie oette lacane, il n’y a pas d’appa-rence que ces clauses soient mieux observeefc k l’avenir. II y aurait bien d’autres points faibles k relever dans le projet de reorganisation muni-cipale, tels que l’avanoement routinier des employes, le favoritisme, le systfcme des adjudications, la maniere de voter dans les assembles, etc. mais ces considerations, qai nons entralneraient trop loin, feront l’objet d’un prochain article. Qa’il noas saflfne pour aajour-d’hui d’avoir signale la necesaite d’un comite de contrdle pour veiller k l’execution des r6gle-mente et recevoir les reclamations, comite d’oil il faudra explore evidemmeat tout fonc tionnaire de la Manioipalite et toot membre de la Commission.

div.head: LE COMMERCE DE L ECYPTE
div.p: La quote-part Allemande Les soins mis par l’Al’emagne, dans ces der-ni^res annees, k aiueiiorer ses relations com-morciales dans le Levant, ont eu egalement leur repercussion en Egypte. Les importations d’Allemagne dans ce pays ont passe de 13 millions de marks en 1897, ^ 57 en 1903; dans le mSme laps de temps, les exportations d’Egypte en Allemagne ont progreasse de 7 k 22 millions de marks. Ces augmentations so sont poursuivies en*1904; les satistiques sont donnees en livres egyptiennes et fournissent -les cbitfres suivants : * Importations en Egypte: 1903, 792.924 livres egyptiennes; 1904, 1.020.269 livres egyptiennes. Exportations en Allemagne; 1903,1.540.000 livres egyptiennes; 1904,1.800.000 livres egyptiennes. Daha lea importations, l’Allemagne n’occupe encore que le sixifcme rang: les prinoipaux prodnita qu’elle envoie en Egypte aont d’abord les articles de fer et d’acier; en 1904, il en est entre, en Egypte, pour 239,000 livres egyptiennes; ce chiffre n’est depasse que par celui des importations anglaisea de mfime nature, qui s’eievent k 551.000 livre8 egyptiennes. Le.s tissus et matinrea textiles sont la par tie la plus importante de l’importation egyptien* ne; la part de 1’Allemagne, dans ce genre, eat de 256.000 livrea egyptiennea; celle de l’Angleterre, bien qn’en diminution, e8t encore de 3.734.000 livre8 egyptiennes. Les autres produits principaux venant d’Al* lemagne sont: Les faiences, porcelaines et verreries, 42.375 livrea egyptiennes; meubles, 30’303 livres egyptiennea; couleurs, 28.961 livrea egyptiennes ; biere, 21.559 livres egyptiennes; puis les articles en cuivre et laiton, la papeterie, les medicaments et produits chimiques, etc. An point de vue des exportations d’Egypto, l’Allemagne prend, en 1904, la deaxifcme place qai, jasqu’alora, appartenait k la France; le commerce allemand a passe de 1.540.000 livres egyptiennea en 1903 k 1.800.000livres egyptiennes en 1904, pendant qae les achats de la France paasaient en sens inverse, de 1.690.000 livres egyptiennes, k 1.620.000 livres egyptiennes. C’est, bien entendu, le coton qui forme la majeure partie des exportations : 1’Allemagne en a achete, en 1904, pour 1.500.000 livres egyptiennes, soit 200.000 livres egyptiennes de pins qu’en 1903 ; la France, au oontraire, en achetait pour 100.000 livres egyptiennes de moins, Ces brillants resultats sont imputes d’abord k la valeur des voyageura de commerce alle-mands, dont le Con8ul general d’autriche-Hon-grie en Egypte vantait, dans son dernier rapport annuel, l’intelligence et la tenacity, et ensuite aux efforts faits par les Compagnies de navigation allemandes. Ces derni^res ont fon-de, il y a quelques anneea, k Port-Said, an dep6t de charbon poor lequel 63jOOO tonnes de charbon ont 6t6 expedies l’an derpier. Le Lloyd a organise, en 1904, on servioe regulier entre Marseille, Naples et Alexandrie, qai n’a pas tarde k attirer k lui marchandises et pas-sagers, pour le plus grand dommage dea Me8->£igeriea Maritimea. De plus, la Compagnie Hambourgeoise americaine fait eonstruire six vapeurs fluviaux destines a l’etablissement d’un service regulier pour les voyageura et les marchandises sur le Nil. Eafin, on parle de creer prochainement, en Egypte, une banqne allemande, succuraale jle la banqne d’Orient, recemment fondee k Athfemes. — (Communication de M. Bihourd, ambassadeur de France k Berlin.)

div.head: Grefifes et Tribonaux Indigenes
div.p: Le ministere de la justice a eiabore un projet tendant k unifier les bureaux des greffe3 des tribunaux et parquets indigenes en las divisant en denx categories distinctes, l’une civile et l’autre criminelle. L’arrfite y relatif sera probablement mis en vigueur au commencement de l’annee prochaine.

div.head: Egyptiao Investment n Agency, Limited.
div.p: AVIS ' Le 8 Jain 1905, de 9 à 12 h. a.m. et de 8 à 5 h. p.m., l’Egyptian Investment and Agency Limited, recevrade3demandes d’achat de 75,000 actions ordinaires de £1 de la nouvelle Société "Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt Ld’’ au prix net de 40 shellings l’une, sans courtage, payables : 10 sh.» à la demande ; 10 sh. lorsque le nombre des actions qui pourront être cédées aux acheteurs leur sera notifié ; et le solde, soit £1, le 21 Juin 1905. Si le nombre des actions demandées dépasse çelui des actions actuellement offertes, les ventes seront faites au prorata des demandes avec un minimum de cinq actions. Le capital ordinaire de "L’Associatbd Cotton Ginners of Egypt Ld” est de £360,000, destinées à rémunérer l’apport des usine? parmi lesquelles figurent notamment oelles appartenant à: MM. Carver Bros, and Co. Ld* Choremi Benachi and Co., J. Planta and Co., C. M. Salvago and Co., C. G. Zervudachi and Co>, et à la Société d’Egrenage de Zagazig. Il ne pourra être émis de nouvelles aotions que jusqu’à concurrence de £40,000 au maximum, et cela par simple décision du Conseil d’Adminiatration. Le premier Conseil d’Administration sera ainsi composé : M. C. de Tschudi, Président MM. E. A. Benachi, S. Carver, Vice? Présidents MM. R. C.^.bdy, C. Bacos, Michel Sinadino, Membres Le Directeur de la Société est M. Alex. Th. Kitroeff. A partir du 21 Juin 1905 l’Egyptianluvest-ment n Agency Ld. délivrera, dans ses bureaux à Alexandrie, des certificats provisoires contre restitution de3 quittances justificatives des trois versements ci-dessus indiqués. Ces certificats donneront droit aux porteurs à des Actions définitives entièrement libérées, dès que celles-ci seront prêtes à être échangées ce dott les intéressés seront dûment avisés. 26,083-2-1 s AVIS La Compagnie Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez mettra en adjudication, k Iamailia, le 19 Juin couranty des travaux de conatraction de perres s’eievant a environ : 100,000 francs, et trois lotade terrassements k sec d’une importance totale de 432,50(0 m3. Les entrepreneurs qui desireraient conoourir k ces quatre adjudications devront en faire la demande k l lngenieurenchef de la Compagnie avant le 12 Juin et donner des references. 26081 1
